responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Insecure direct object reference in admin functionality
    analysis: |
      The JavaScript code in assets/js/admin.js directly manipulates DOM elements based on user input without proper sanitization or authorization checks. This can lead to issues where malicious scripts could be injected or unintended actions could be triggered by manipulating the DOM elements directly from the browser console or through crafted payloads.
    cwe: CWE-22
    function_names:
      - prettyTextDiff
    filenames:
      - assets/js/admin.js
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Command injection possibility in Grunt configuration
    analysis: |
      The Grunt configuration file 'Gruntfile.js' dynamically constructs shell commands based on input which includes composer bin paths. If the composer bin path or any part involved in command construction can be controlled by an attacker or ends up being tampered with by other malicious modifications or misconfigurations, it could lead to command injection vulnerabilities.
    cwe: CWE-77
    function_names:
      - shell
    filenames:
      - Gruntfile.js
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Lack of input validation for multi-select jQuery plugin
    analysis: |
      The jQuery multi-select plugin in 'assets/js/multiselect/jquery.multiselect.js' does not validate or encode the input from the select options it constructs dynamically. This could potentially lead to cross-site scripting (XSS) if the option values contain executable code or markup injected by an attacker.
    cwe: CWE-79
    function_names:
      - MultiSelect
    filenames:
      - assets/js/multiselect/jquery.multiselect.js
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Uncontrolled resource consumption due to recursive entity references
    analysis: |
      The code in the included third-party library 'assets/js/pretty-text-diff/diff_match_patch.js' appears to use recursive methods to compute differences without proper termination or depth handling. This could potentially lead to denial of service (DoS) via deeply nested recursive calls or extremely long input sequences that could exhaust system resources.
    cwe: CWE-674
    function_names:
      - diff_match_patch
    filenames:
      - assets/js/pretty-text-diff/diff_match_patch.js
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Potential XPath injection in jQuery prettyTextDiff plugin
    analysis: |
      The 'assets/js/pretty-text-diff/jquery.pretty-text-diff.js' script processes differences in textual content. It involves the manipulation and placement of user-controlled data into HTML without escaping, potentially leading to injection flaws such as XPath injection if this input is processed further in XML or similar technologies.
    cwe: CWE-91
    function_names:
      - prettyTextDiff
    filenames:
      - assets/js/pretty-text-diff/jquery.pretty-text-diff.js
    classification: slightly promising

  - headline: Server-side request forgery (SSRF) risk in Gruntfile network operations
    analysis: |
      In 'Gruntfile.js', the 'gitinfo' and 'checkrepo' tasks interact with external Git repositories. If the repository URLs or other Git parameters are externally influenced or not adequately validated, this could lead to SSRF where the Grunt tasks could be manipulated to interact with unintended servers or services.
    cwe: CWE-918
    function_names:
      - gitinfo
      - checkrepo
    filenames:
      - Gruntfile.js
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Insecure direct object reference in admin functionality
leads.analysis: The JavaScript code in assets/js/admin.js directly manipulates DOM elements based on user input without proper sanitization or authorization checks. This can lead to issues where malicious scripts could be injected or unintended actions could be triggered by manipulating the DOM elements directly from the browser console or through crafted payloads.

leads.headline: Command injection possibility in Grunt configuration
leads.analysis: The Grunt configuration file 'Gruntfile.js' dynamically constructs shell commands based on input which includes composer bin paths. If the composer bin path or any part involved in command construction can be controlled by an attacker or ends up being tampered with by other malicious modifications or misconfigurations, it could lead to command injection vulnerabilities.

leads.headline: Lack of input validation for multi-select jQuery plugin
leads.analysis: The jQuery multi-select plugin in 'assets/js/multiselect/jquery.multiselect.js' does not validate or encode the input from the select options it constructs dynamically. This could potentially lead to cross-site scripting (XSS) if the option values contain executable code or markup injected by an attacker.

leads.headline: Uncontrolled resource consumption due to recursive entity references
leads.analysis: The code in the included third-party library 'assets/js/pretty-text-diff/diff_match_patch.js' appears to use recursive methods to compute differences without proper termination or depth handling. This could potentially lead to denial of service (DoS) via deeply nested recursive calls or extremely long input sequences that could exhaust system resources.

leads.headline: Potential XPath injection in jQuery prettyTextDiff plugin
leads.analysis: The 'assets/js/pretty-text-diff/jquery.pretty-text-diff.js' script processes differences in textual content. It involves the manipulation and placement of user-controlled data into HTML without escaping, potentially leading to injection flaws such as XPath injection if this input is processed further in XML or similar technologies.

leads.headline: Server-side request forgery (SSRF) risk in Gruntfile network operations
leads.analysis: In 'Gruntfile.js', the 'gitinfo' and 'checkrepo' tasks interact with external Git repositories. If the repository URLs or other Git parameters are externally influenced or not adequately validated, this could lead to SSRF where the Grunt tasks could be manipulated to interact with unintended servers or services.
